Graphical abstract Highlights ► CuO oxide nanopowders are efficient catalysts of the low temperature CO oxidation. ► Oxygen deficiencies results in disproportionation of CuO lattice oxygen on two species. ► The weakly charged oxygen species is reactive toward CO and responsible for LTO. ► A decrease of Cu charge without Cu1+ formation facilitates CO adsorption at lower temperatures. CuO nanopowders were prepared by precipitation from alkaline solutions and were studied by TPR-CO+O2, XRD, TGA, TPD-He and XPS. All of the precipitated samples were characterized by excellent catalytic properties toward the low-temperature (LT) oxidation of CO with similar T 50 values of 110°C. In contrast, bulk CuO oxides with sizes greater than 450nm exhibited no activity at low temperatures. Several monolayers of chemisorbed species, such as water/hydroxyls and carbonate/hydrocarbonates, were typically observed at the surface of the nanopowders. These species were not critical for the LT oxidation of CO, and their preliminary removal did not substantially change the activity of the nanopowders. XPS results indicated a high deficiency of the oxygen sublattice of the CuO1−x (x =0.1–0.15) nanopowders, whereas, for the lattice of bulk CuO, the Cu/O ratio was 1. The highly deficient oxygen sublattice resulted in a disproportionation process, which, in turn, resulted in two observed oxygen forms. An oxygen form with E b(O1s)=531.3eV that is highly reactive toward CO was proposed to be responsible for the high catalytic activity of the CuO nanopowders. Slight differences in the Cu2p shake-up satellite structures were observed between the bulk and nanosized samples, which indicated that the electronic structure in the cationic sublattice had changed. Keywords CuO nanoparticles Low-temperature CO oxidation XPS 1 Introduction Copper-containing compounds are important subjects of inquiry for various applications: ecology (the solar batteries [1] and gas sensors [2]), electronics (Li-ion batteries [3] and magnetic storage [4]), optics (photovoltaic devices [5] and optical switches [6]), materials science (high-temperature superconductors [7]). Different copper-containing systems in supported [8,9] or unsupported states [10,11] are used in a wide range of relevant heterogeneous catalysis processes: steam methanol reforming [12,13], NO reduction [14,15], CO oxidation [16,17] and PROX [18,19]. The catalytic oxidation of CO has been studied for several decades using various copper-containing catalysts, including copper single crystals [20,21], thin copper oxide films [22,23], oxidized bulk copper [24], copper oxide powders [16,25–29] and supported systems [17,18,30,31]. This interest is supported by the development of problems in applied heterogeneous catalysis as well as by an understanding of the catalytic activity of copper from a fundamental point of view. Jernigan and Somorjai [22] showed that the activity of copper was influenced by its oxidation state. The CO oxidation activity at 300°C decreased as copper was further oxidized (Cu>Cu2O>CuO). Huang et al. [27] investigated the activity of copper-containing systems in CO oxidation as a function of the number of surface lattice oxygen ions. The best activity was observed for Cu2O in comparison with metallic copper and cupric oxide (CuO). The high activity was attributed to metastable non-stoichiometric phases that exhibit the ability to transport surface lattice oxygen. Nagase et al. [28] found that bulk CuO powder was more active in the CO+O2 oxidation reaction than bulk Cu2O powder, whereas CuO prepared by the oxidation of Cu2O was less active than the initial Cu2O powder. The cumulative data on the catalytic properties of CuO x systems may not allow a definition of which copper state is required to achieve the best activity because numerous factors influence its catalytic properties. The works of Sadykov et al. [29,32] address this problem. The real/defect structure of copper–oxygen systems have to be taken into account during an investigation of catalytic properties. Moreover, the electronic surface structure and the oxidative activity are well known to depend not only on the defect structure but also on the particle size [33], shape [34] and porosity [35] of the catalyst. A large amount of literature has been devoted to investigations of the size effect, which, as a rule, causes changes in the physical and/or chemical properties of catalysts [36–39]. The nanosize effect is important in heterogeneous catalysis because it promotes the appearance or intensification of catalytic activity [40–42], including that of oxidized copper nanoparticles [25,26,34]. The use of CuO nanoparticles can significantly decrease a catalytic reaction temperature (NH4ClO4 decomposition [34] and methanol oxidation [26]), including that of CO oxidation [24,43,44]. In this regard, the CuO synthesized by Pillai and Deevi [16] for the catalysis of CO oxidation at room temperature (<30°C) is noteworthy because commercial samples of Cu2O and Cu oxidized CO only at temperatures greater than 100°C. The process of the LT CO oxidation is highly relevant for the oxidation of automotive exhausts and for the PROX reaction. However, the nature of the size effect of copper-containing systems is still unclear. One of the factors that influences catalytic activity in oxidative reactions is the possibility of stabilizing weakly bound oxygen forms [45,46]. The oxidation ability of active oxygen in LTO reactions can be determined through characterization of the electronic surface structure, which strongly depends on various factors, including particle size. Therefore, the study of electronic-structure features and their influence on catalytic properties for nanosized copper oxide is an important scientific task. In this work, highly dispersed CuO powders were synthesized via the precipitation of cupric salts from alkaline solution. The particle morphology, surface composition and catalytic properties were studied using physicochemical techniques. The differences in catalytic activity between nanosized and bulk copper oxides are discussed in terms of the oxygen and copper oxidation states and in terms of peculiarities in the electronic structure of CuO nanopowders. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation The highly dispersed copper(II) oxides were prepared by precipitation from cupric salt solutions using an excess of 40wt% NaOH solution. The black precipitates were repeatedly washed with distilled water to neutral pH, filtered and air-dried at room temperature for 2–3 days. The experimental conditions were widely varied with respect to the precursor copper salt (denominator designates a reference: Cu(OAc)2/A, OAc – acetate; Cu(NO3)2/N; CuSO4/S; H2[CuCl4]/Cl), the concentration (0.2 or 0.5M), the solvent (water; water–ethanol or water–acetone mixtures), and the reaction temperature (25–100°C). For the synthesis of the CuO–Np samples, 30wt% H2O2 was added to the solution at the precipitate formation stage. The specific preparation conditions are presented in Table 1 . The sample designation was chosen to be consistent with the experimental conditions: the previously mentioned symbols denote precursors; the numbers 20, 40, 60, and E80 designate the solvent ratio: acetone: water=20:80, 40:60, 60:40 and ethanol: water=80:20, respectively; T100 denotes a sample precipitated at ∼100°C; p (in CuO Np) indicates that H2O2 was added. The commercial cupric oxide (Urals Plant of Chemicals Reagents, V. Pyshma, Russia) (CuO-bulk) and CuO-S dispersed cupric oxide powder that was air-annealed at 850°C for 2h (CuO-S850) were used as reference samples. In addition, cuprous oxide, Cu2O, was prepared by the mild reduction of copper(II) sulfate using glucose as the reducing agent in alkaline medium at 65°C. The red precipitate of Cu2O was also air-dried at room temperature. 2.2 X-ray diffraction Measurements of the phase composition were performed on a Bruker D8 GADDS diffractometer equipped with a Hi-Star two-coordinate detector, a Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54184Å) source, a graphite monochromator, and a 0.5mm collimator. The high-voltage generator was set to 40kV and 40mA. The range of the reflection angles was 10–90° (four frames). The distance from the sample to the detector was 25cm. The angle range of captured by one frame was greater than 20 (for superposing the diffraction patterns). The data collection and analyses were performed with the GADDS 4.1.02 and EVA (Bruker AXS) software packages. Powder diffraction patterns were calculated using PowderCell 2.4 [47]. The coherent-scattering region (CSR) was estimated by the Williamson–Hall method using all observed reflections [48]; the relative error was ∼10%. 2.3 Specific surface area The surface area values were calculated by BET theory based on the low-temperature N2 adsorption using a Sorbi N.4.1 surface analyzer; the relative error was ≤6% [49]. 2.4 Chemical analysis The copper content was measured by means of chelatometric titration with EDTA at pH=7–8. All analyzed samples were first dissolved in 5wt% HCl solution. Murexide (ammonium salt of purpuric acid) was used as an indicator. For each sample, at least five parallel analyses were performed. The results of the copper content measurements are presented in Table 2 . 2.5 Thermogravimetry CuO samples (50mg) were heated in helium at a flow rate of 30ml/min in the temperature range from 20 to 1000°C. The heating rate was 10°C/min. 2.6 Catalytic properties The activity of CuO powders was measured by means of a temperature-programmed reaction of CO+O2 (TPR-CO+O2) using an automatic setup equipped with a flow reactor and a mass-spectrometer for analysis of gaseous mixtures. An initial sample for TPR-CO+O2 analysis with a 0.5–0.25mm size fraction was loaded into a stainless steel reactor. The reaction mixture that contained 0.2% CO, 1.0% O2, and 0.5% Ne (balance He) was introduced into the reactor at a rate of 1000ml/min. The volume rate of flow was maintained equal to 240,000h−1 for all tested catalysts. Each sample was twice heated from −10 to 450°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min and was intermediately cooled to room temperature in the reaction mixture. In the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments, the samples were heated under pure helium. The initial reaction rate (W), stated as the quantity of CO molecules oxidized per cm2 per second, was calculated using the starting interval of the catalytic curves when the CO conversion was no more than 15%. Such curve sections correspond to the kinetic limitation of the reaction and are the most reliable data for the calculation of the reaction rate. The expression of reaction rate in Arrhenius coordinates provided the apparent activation energy (E a). The turnover frequency (TOF) was standardized as the quantity of oxidized CO molecules at one surface Cu atom per second. The surface density was assumed to be ∼1015 Cu atoms/cm2. 2.7 Transmission electron microscopy The particle morphology was studied by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy using a JEM-2010 (JEOL, Japan) microscope with a lattice resolution of 0.14nm and an accelerating voltage of 200kV. The crystal lattice images were analyzed by the Fourier method. Carbon films of thickness ca. 10nm fixed on a standard copper grid were used as substrates. The size distributions of the particles were constructed using the ImageJ freeware software program based on MS-Windows [50]. 2.8 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy experiments were performed using ES-300 Kratos Analytical and VG ESCALAB HP photoelectron spectrometers. The latter instrument was equipped with the analyzer and the preparation chambers. MgKα (hυ =1253.6eV) and AlKα (hυ =1486.6eV) X-ray sources were used to record the spectra after the samples were transferred to the analyzer chamber. The source power was 65W for the Mg anode and 100W for the Al anode. No sample reduction was observed during spectra acquisition. The diameter of the X-ray beam was approximately 8mm. The O1s, Cu2p, C1s and Cu LMM spectral regions were recorded to study the charge state of the corresponding elemental species. To determine the level of surface contamination, high-sensitivity survey spectra were recorded. The samples for analysis before and after the catalytic tests were mounted on the surface of double-sided carbon sticky tape. The CuO-S copper(II) oxide was pressed into stainless steel wire mesh for experiments with sample heating and treatments by gases (CO and O2). The metal mesh with the pressed sample was heated by resistive mode in 100Pa of oxygen to 350°C to remove surface-adsorbed species. A chromel–alumel thermocouple was used to measure the temperature. The spectrometer calibration was performed using relatively bulk gold (Au4f7/2) and copper (Cu2p3/2) photoelectron lines with BE values of 84.0 and 932.7eV, respectively. The position of the C1s line, 284.8eV, was used as a standard reference for calibration of the spectra. No charging effect was observed for CuO-S pressed into the mesh. The chemical composition of surface was quantitatively determined from integral peak areas using standard atomic sensitivity factors (ASFs) [51]. Processing of the obtained data and spectral analyses (curve fitting, area calculation, difference spectra, etc.) were performed using the XPS-Calc program, which has been tested on a number of systems [52–57]. The curve fitting procedure was performed using an approximation based on a combination of the Gaussian and Lorentzian functions with subtraction of a Shirley-type background. Before the curve fitting, all experimental spectra were smoothed using a Fourier filter. No considerable difference between the smoothed and experimental curves was observed; the mean-square deviation was less than 1%. 3 Results 3.1 XRD analysis Copper oxides were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (Fig. 1 ). Analysis of the X-ray patterns showed that all samples except the prepared Cu2O and CuO-bulk were pure copper(II) oxide crystal phases (monoclinic lattice) that did not contain crystallized impurities. X-ray peaks of the precipitated samples were considerably broadened, which indicated a small crystallite size. The calculated CSR values varied in the range from 9 to 21nm (Table 2) for the precipitated powders, which confirmed their highly dispersed state. In the X-ray pattern of CuO-bulk sample (CSR ∼142nm), additional Cu2O reflections (cubic lattice) were also observed (Fig. 1). Because CuO-bulk is a commercial sample, the reason for the presence of the Cu2O phase is unknown. Notably, the CuO-bulk phase was used as reference sample during our investigation of electronic structure and catalytic activity. The other reference sample, CuO-S850 (CSR ∼89nm), which was prepared by CuO-S calcination at 850°C, consisted of pure CuO bulk phase with narrow X-ray diffraction peaks (Fig. 1). To establish the influence of the Cu2O phase on the catalytic properties, a pure Cu2O sample was synthesized. In the X-ray pattern of Cu2O, only narrow cubic phase reflections were observed, with a CSR of ∼41nm (Fig. 1 and Table 2). All of the precipitated CuO samples were nanosized copper(II) oxides with crystallite sizes from 9 to 21nm. The precipitation conditions did not significantly influence the CSR of the CuO nanopowders. 3.2 Stoichiometry and surface composition of the copper oxides (BET method, chelatometric titration, TGA/TPD-He) Specific surface areas, as measured by the BET method, are presented in Table 2. The surface areas for nanosized copper(II) oxides varied in the range from 28 to 79m2/g, whereas the corresponding values for the bulk samples (CuO-bulk, CuO-S850) were less than 1m2/g, which confirms that the crystallites were large. The surface area of the pure Cu2O sample was 1.7m2/g. The calculated CSR values correlate well with the BET data: the greatest surface area corresponds to the smallest crystallite sizes and vice versa (Table 2). To explain the catalytic activity of copper oxides, other authors have frequently discussed other suboxidic phases (such as Cu3O2 or Cu4O3) or non-stoichiometric phases [16,28]. Such phases can stabilize active oxygen at the surface. To shed light on the presence of metastable phases in our systems, the copper content in the samples was analyzed by chelatometry. The obtained data are presented in Table 2. For an ideal CuO sample that consists only of oxygen (Ar(O)=15.999a.e.m.) and copper (Ar(Cu)=63.546a.e.m.), the copper mass fraction has to be 79.9%. The experimental copper mass fraction for the majority of the dispersed samples was ∼75.0±0.5% (Table 2), whereas it was 80.4 and 78.5% for CuO-bulk and CuO-S850, respectively. Because a Cu2O phase was found in the CuO-bulk sample, the Cu content (80.4%) was slightly high for this specimen, whereas the Cu content in the highly dispersed samples was always ∼2.5–3% lower than that in the bulk oxides. This decreased Cu content in the highly dispersed samples can be related not only to the formation of metastable phases, but also to the presence of surface hydroxyl or/and carbonate/hydrocarbonate groups that results from the lack of a temperature pretreatment of the precipitated samples and from their high surface area. To support this hypothesis, different CuO samples were studied using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and temperature-programmed desorption under a helium atmosphere (TPD-He). The TGA results for CuO-N40, CuO-NE80 and CuO-bulk are presented in Fig. 2(a). The TGA curves of the highly dispersed CuO differed significantly from the corresponding curves of the bulk sample (Fig. 2). Mass losses for CuO-bulk were barely observed up to 800°C. All of the samples studied by TGA decomposed under helium Cu2O at ∼960°C (weight losses ∼10%). For nanosized CuO, mass-loss peaks (DTGA curves) at 78 and 265°C were also observed. The integral decreases in weight for CuO-N40 and CuO-NE80 heated to 400°C were found to be ∼2.4 and 4wt%, respectively. To define the nature of the desorbed species, the TPD-He analysis was performed for CuO-N40 (Fig. 2(b)). The evolutions of H2O, CO2 and O2 were observed in the overall temperature range up to 400°C with corresponding emissions of ∼2200, 500 and 180μmol/g (0.176, 0.04 and 0.014mol/mol of sample), respectively. The evolution of oxygen was probably related to the desorption or/and partial decomposition of CuO/Cu(OH)2 to Cu2O/CuOH, such as might occur at the surface. As seen in Fig. 2(a) and (b), only water was desorbed at 78°C, and the DTGA peak at 265°C is in good agreement with the TPD peak at 275°C, which corresponds to the simultaneous desorption of H2O and CO2. At temperatures greater than 220°C, symbatic behavior of the TPD-curves for CO2 and H2O desorption was observed. This behavior is related to the decomposition of surface/subsurface copper(II) hydroxylcarbonate, Cu2(OH)2CO3, as follows: (1) Cu 2 ( OH ) 2 CO 3 → 2 CuO + H 2 O ( g ) + CO 2 ( g ) Taking into an account the quantity of adsorbed species, the recalculation of the Cu content in the dispersed samples by chelatometry resulted in a Cu content of approximately ∼77wt%. This result can indicate the presence of additional species, such as remaining amorphous or graphite-like carbon. This carbon could not be removed by heating the samples under helium. Therefore, without measurements of the surface admixtures, the bulk stoichiometry of the nanosized copper oxides could not be accurately determined. The surface CuO stoichiometry will be discussed later. The quantitative estimation of gas evolution during TPD experiments for CuO-N40 (S =68m2/g) was approximately 2–3 monolayers of water, oxygen, carbonate and hydroxyl groups at the surface. According to the TGA results, this value for the CuO-NE80 sample has to be 1.5 times greater. 3.3 Electron microscopy The as-prepared CuO nanopowders before and after the catalytic tests were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (Fig. 3 ). Precipitated CuO samples consisted primarily of sheet- or needle-like particles. Their sizes were dependent on the preparation conditions. For, example, CuO-N40 consisted of particles with an average width and length of d m =35nm and l m =195nm, respectively, in accordance with the particle size distribution (Fig. 3 and Table 2). The particle length was observed to be significantly varied: for the most highly dispersed copper(II) oxide, CuO NE80 (surface area 77m2/g, SCR ∼9nm, Table 2), the particle length varied from 20 to 300nm, whereas for the least dispersed nanopowder, CuO-Np (surface area 28m2/g, CSR ∼21nm), the particle length ranged from 100 to 1000nm or more. Analysis of the TEM and XRD data resulted in the identification of the sheet- or needle-like particle growth direction as [010], which is in good agreement with previously published results [58,59]. As seen in Fig. 3 and Table 2, the variation of the precursor type (CuO-A, CuO-N, CuO-S and CuO-Cl samples) and solvent (specimen row: CuO-N20, CuO-N40 and CuO-N60) can significantly influence the linear sizes of the precipitated particles. The observed overall width range for prepared nanopowders was 10–150nm, whereas the corresponding range of particle lengths was 20–30 to 1000–1500nm. In Fig. 3, the TEM images for the CuO-S850 and CuO-bulk reference samples are also presented. These specimens contain large monolithic particles with sizes ≥450nm; the sizes of these particles differed significantly from those of the precipitated copper(II) oxides. The synthesized Cu2O sample contained large particles with sizes ≥650nm (Table 2). According to electron diffraction data (not presented), the particles of nanopowders before and after catalytic tests were mainly characterized by the crystal structure of CuO (interplanar spacing: d 110 =2.75Å, d 002 = d −111 =2.53Å, d 111 =2.32Å). As evident in Fig. 3, the shapes of the particles changed from sheet-/needle-like to round-like after the treatment by the reaction mixture. The average particle size after catalysis was found to be slightly larger than the average width of the initial sheets/needles. The particle size distributions are presented for the CuO-N20 and N40 specimens in Fig. 3. Analysis of high-resolution images showed that, after treatment by the reaction mixture, a thin (∼1–2nm) Cu2O epitaxial layer (interplanar spacing: d 110 =3.02Å, d 111 =2.47Å, d 200 =2.13Å) formed at the surface. The observed interplanar spacings for Cu2O and CuO are in good agreement with those reported in the literature ([60], CC=69757 and [61], CC=172174, ICSD database). No Cu2O and Cu0 phases were observed in the X-ray patterns of the dispersed CuO samples after the catalytic tests. The CSR value was slightly higher after the treatment by the reaction mixture than for the initial state of the CuO nanopowders. For example, the CSR of CuO-Np increased from 21 to 33nm. This fact further confirmed the enlargement of the particles after the catalytic tests, as indicated by the TEM results (Fig. 3). Notably, the initial nanopowders, in contrast to the bulk samples, were unstable under the electron beam of the microscope. This instability was probably related to the partial reduction or the removal of adsorbed species, such as water/hydroxyls and/or carbonates/hydrocarbonates, due to local sample heating. This process could result in the formation of CuO mesocrystals [62]. Such mesocrystals usually retain their initial crystal shape, but contain numerous structural defects. The appearance of mesopores and an increase in their number was observed for CuO nanoparticles when the exposure of the sample to the electron-beam was enhanced. Epitaxial Cu2O layers were also observed at the surface of the CuO particles (as in the case of samples exposed by the reaction medium) after the beam was deliberately enhanced. Therefore, the exposure of the samples to the electron beam simulated the catalytic conditions. 3.4 Catalytic properties (TPR-CO+O2) The temperature of low-temperature activity (LTA) toward CO oxidation with 50% CO conversion (T 50) was found be in the range of 104–134°C for all the characterized CuO nanopowders (Table 2 and Fig. 4(a)). The start of the reaction was defined as the temperature of 10% CO conversion (T 10), which varied for nanosized samples from 65 to 103°C (Table 2 and Fig. 4(a)). As shown in Fig. 4(a), the CuO-Np sample was characterized by T 10 and T 50 values that were slightly higher than those of the other dispersed nanopowders, including CuO-N and CuO N60, whereas the particles widths of these specimens were the same. Therefore, no significant changes in the catalytic properties of the precipitated nanopowders were observed. However, the catalytic activities of the reference bulk samples were considerably different from those of the nanopowders. For the CuO-bulk and Cu2O samples, the T 10 and T 50 values were approximately ∼200 and ∼250°C (Fig. 4(b)), respectively. The bulk CuO-S850 sample prepared by the calcination of CuO-S at 850°C was similar to the CuO-bulk and Cu2O powders and did not react with CO at temperatures less than 150°C. The T 10 and T 50 values compiled in Table 2 were defined for the second run (Up-2, Fig. 4(c)) in the catalytic measurements. The CO conversion curves under successive heating and cooling for the CuO-N40 sample are presented in Fig. 4(c). The observed hysteresis in the CO conversion between “cooling” and “heating” curves is usually explained by the sample overheating due to the exothermic CO oxidation reaction [63,64]. For all samples, the curves of the second runs were shifted to lower temperatures comparison with curves obtained during the first heating. Thereupon, the T 50 value varied in the range of 15–25°C. This variation of the T 50 value is probably related to the removal of chemisorbed surface species (H2O/OH−, CO3 2−/HCO3 −), which can modify the properties of the catalyst surface and the catalytic behavior. Active species can be immediately formed in the reaction conditions and can differ from the initial species on the surface. Therefore, the T 10 and T 50 values determined from the second-run curves are more correct than those determined from the first-run heating or cooling curves. Table 3 lists the TOF values of copper nanopowders at 80, 90 and 100°C calculated from catalytic data. The dependence of TOF on the specific surface area of the CuO nanopowders is plotted in Fig. 5(a). The general behavior of TOF is similar for all of the dispersed CuO samples irrespective of their surface area, in accordance with Boreskov's rule [65]. The mean TOFs varied near ∼0.001s−1 and ∼0.0015s−1 at 80 and 90°C, respectively (Table 3 and Fig. 5(a)). Fig. 5(b) presents Arrhenius plots of the start of the catalytic curves for the CuO nanopowders, and the apparent activation energy E a values were estimated from these plots. The observed deviations of the calculated values occur due to incompatible standardization of TOFs using only surface area values whereas kinetics scheme, the structure of the active sites and the morphological features of the samples were not considered. The apparent activation energy of CO oxidation over the CuO nanopowders was approximately 60kJ/mol (Table 3). The calculated E a for the CuO-bulk, CuO-S850 and Cu2O samples resulted in values of ∼65–90kJ/mol, which directly denotes that, in CO oxidation, the activation energy is higher when bulk samples are used. Notably, the temperature range used in the determination of E a for the bulk specimens was 170–200°C, which is greater than that used for the CuO nanopowders. Based on data in Tables 2 and 3 and in Fig. 5, we concluded that the preparation conditions of the CuO nanopowders (such as the type of precursor, the concentration of the copper salt, and the type of solvent) significantly influence the linear particle sizes (width and length); however, their LTA does not change significantly. Also, the comparison of bulk-CuO and nanopowders allows conclusions to be drawn about the disappearance of low-temperature activity for extended phases during CO oxidation irrespective of the phase composition (CuO, Cu2O, and a mixture of CuO and Cu2O). To elucidate the influence of adsorbed species (H2O/OH−, CO3 2−/HCO3 −) at the nanopowders surface on the catalytic properties during CO oxidation, the CuO-N40 sample was tested under catalytic conditions immediately after the TPD-He experiments (heating to 400°С) in the absence of access for air. The catalytic conditions were the same as those used for the initial CuO-N40 sample (Fig. 6 ). As evident in Fig. 6, the T 10 value for all the curves is similar (∼75°C), whereas the T 50 value for the curve after the TPD-He treatment (∼112°C) negligibly differs from the corresponding value for the first (∼104°C) and second (∼120°C) heating runs of the as-prepared CuO-N40 sample. Therefore, the presence of chemisorbed species at the surface of the nanopowders is not a relevant factor for low-temperature CO oxidation. The sample treatment at 400°C under an inert atmosphere should be the standard procedure for the pretreatment of CuO nanopowders. The shift of the CO conversion curve in the second run to lower temperatures (Fig. 6) can be explained by the desorption of surface admixtures, which was followed by the appearance of additional active sites. Such shift can also be related to the change of CuO particles morphology during catalytic tests, which was observed by TEM (Fig. 3). Zhou et al. [43] showed that nanoplatelets of CuO possess higher activity in CO oxidation, than CuO nanobelts and round-like particles. So the improvement of catalytic properties can be caused by the modification of reactive surface, or change of particle morphology, or both of these factors. The mismatch between the CO conversion curve in the second run and the curve after the TPD-He experiment can be related to a different quantity of active sites. We propose that the “heating–cooling” catalytic cycle resulted not only in the removal of chemisorbed species (as in the case of the TPD-He experiment), but also in the appearance of active oxygen states due to the oxidizing nature of the reaction mixture (CO:O2 =1:5). In recent years, the role of hydroxyl OH− groups in CO oxidation over various catalytic systems has been widely debated [66,67]. However, our TGA/TPD-He and TPR-CO+O2 results showed that the removal of chemisorbed species, including hydroxyl groups and water, did not change the catalytic properties of the CuO nanopowders. These results cast doubt on the participation of OH− group in LT CO oxidation by CuO nanopowders. 3.5 Copper and oxygen states at the surface (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) All of the CuO samples were also characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in the as-prepared state and after treatment by the reaction mixture during catalytic properties testing (Fig. 7 ). No chemical elements except Cu, O and C were observed by XPS at the surface of the studied copper oxides. Spectral Cu2p (Fig. 7) and Cu LMM regions (not presented) were used to analyze the copper oxidation state. Nanopowders in the initial samples contained only Cu2+ at the surface, as evidenced by the typical Cu2p3/2 binding energy (933.7eV, Fig. 7) as well as by the presence of intensive shake-up satellites in the range of 940–945eV [68,69]. The ratio of the Cu2p3/2 peak intensity to the shake-up satellite intensity (referred to as F I(Cu2p3/2)/I(shake-up); intensity was calculated as the peak amplitude) was similar for all of the initial nanopowders: F =2.2–2.3. When the Cu1+ state appeared, the simultaneous growth of the Cu2p3/2 peak intensity and a decrease in shake-up satellite intensity resulted in a significant increase in the F-parameter. Therefore, F is a parameter that is highly sensitive to surface Cu1+. For example, the F value for the initial CuO-bulk sample was ∼5.0, which is in 2 times higher than that observed for the pure CuO system, which contained only Cu2+ at the surface. These results also confirmed the XRD data with respect to the presence of a Cu2O phase in the CuO-bulk sample. After the treatment by the reaction mixture, some quantity of Cu1+ (E b(Cu2p3/2)=932.4eV, Fig. 7) was observed at the surface of the dispersed and bulk oxides [22,70]. Such behavior was in good agreement with the TEM data. The concentration of copper(I) ions varied from 29% to 44% of the total copper at the surface (Fig. 7). The O1s-spectral region was used for analysis of the oxygen states (Fig. 7). The typical O1s-spectrum for the initial CuO sample contained a CuO lattice oxygen peak with E b =529.5eV superposed with an additional shoulder in the range of 530.5–533.7eV. The binding energy of the lattice oxygen for the bulk samples (E b =529.8eV [70]) was repeatedly found to be slightly higher than that for the nanopowders (E b =529.5eV). The additional shoulder in the higher energy region of the O1s-spectra was related to the presence of hydroxyl groups (E b(O1s)∼531eV [71]), carbonate/hydrocarbonate groups (E b(O1s)∼531.5eV [72]), and adsorbed water (E b(O1s)∼532.8eV [72]). The presence of CO3 2−/HCO3 − groups at the surface of copper oxides was confirmed by analysis of the C1s-spectra (Fig. 8 ). The CO3 2−/HCO3 − states were observed as peaks with binding energies in the range of 288.0–288.5eV, which is in good agreement with values reported in the literature [73]. No significant difference between the O1s-spectra of the as-prepared bulk and nanosized samples was observed because of a large amount of oxygen-containing chemisorbed species at the surface, which considerably contributed to the integral O1s line. To study the features of the surface electron structure, the simulation of the desorption experiment followed by the investigation by XPS without air exposure was necessary. For surface cleaning, the CuO-S sample was heated in oxygen at 350°С in the preparation chamber of the spectrometer. For the preparation of pure bulk CuO, the initial CuO-S was heated in oxygen at ∼650°С for more than 30min. According to the TEM results, this procedure resulted in sintering of the nanopowder into a bulk sample with particle sizes of approximately 1000–1500nm. In Fig. 8, the О1s- and C1s-spectra of the initial samples of the nanosized and bulk CuO and those collected after their treatment in oxygen are presented. The quantitative XPS data about the surface composition before and after the treatment in O2 are also presented in Table 4 . The calcination of samples in oxygen at 350°С resulted in a significant decrease in the total amount of carbon, including carbonate/hydrocarbonate groups (Table 4 and Fig. 8). The decrease in the amount of surface carbon was accompanied by a decrease in the amount of surface oxygen. To study the surface CuO stoichiometry of the nanopowders, the O/Cu ratio for the bulk CuO sample after it was treated in oxygen was assumed to be equal 1.00. As seen in Table 4, the quantity of oxygen at the surface of the pretreated nanosized CuO was found to be ∼10% less than that at the surface of the bulk oxide. Notably, the O1s-spectrum of the pretreated CuO-S sample showed an additional oxygen state with E b =531.3eV (Fig. 8(b)), whereas that for the CuO bulk oxide showed only lattice oxygen (E b =529.8eV). Furthermore, the quantity of CO3 2−/HCO3 − surface residuals was larger for the pretreated bulk oxide than for the CuO nanoparticles (Table 4). The different nature of oxygen at the surfaces of the bulk and the nanosized CuO particles can be caused by the difference in the surface electronic structure in general, including the electronic copper states. In Fig. 9(a), the Cu2p-spectra for the surfaces of bulk and nanosized CuO samples treated in O2 are presented. The Cu2p3/2 peak position for these specimens is the same in both cases (E b(Cu2p3/2)=933.5eV), whereas 0.3eV shift in the peak positions of the shake-up satellites is clearly observed (Fig. 9(a)). Moreover, the intensities of the shake-up satellites were also different: the F parameter for the nanosized sample was found to 2.3, whereas that for the bulk oxide was 2.5. No Cu1+ state is assumed at the surface after the pretreatment in O2 at 350°C. In Fig. 9(a), the difference between the Cu2p-spectra of the bulk and nanosized CuO is also presented and confirms the difference in the satellite structures. The enhancement of the shake-up satellites is related to the Cu2p electron energy losses due to the d9 configuration of Cu2+. Such losses are usually caused by the relaxation of the copper valence electrons, such as the interaction between the Cu3d and O2p orbitals of copper(II) oxide [74,75]. The shake-up satellite structure is possible only for the Cu2+ state, which is characterized by an incomplete 3d level (3d9), whereas the Cu0 (3d104s1) and Cu1+ (3d10) states produce no satellites in the 940–945eV region. The change in the shake-up satellite position and intensity for the nanosized CuO sample relative to those of the bulk oxide indicates the modification of the electronic structure (i.e., the valence band), which influences the catalytic properties. 4 Discussion The variation of the CuO preparation conditions resulted in sheet/needle-like nanoparticles with various linear sizes, which were characterized by similar catalytic behavior in the LT oxidation of CO. Therefore, the size effect was found to not be critical for catalytic activity with in a certain range of sizes, whereas significant enlargement of the CuO particles resulted in a considerable decrease in catalytic activity. The different behavior between the bulk and nanosized CuO in CO oxidation is likely caused by the distinctions in the surface electronic structures of the catalysts. An additional oxygen state with E b(O1s)∼531.3eV (Figs. 8 and 9(c)) was observed at the surface of the CuO nanoparticles. In our previous work, additional oxygen with E b(O1s)=530.9eV was also observed at the surface of nanostructured copper oxide film [53]. The reaction probability of such oxygen species toward CO at 80°C was estimated to be ∼5×10−5. The reaction probability of lattice oxygen was estimated to be less than 5×10−9. In the case of nanopowders, the clean surface of CuO-S was also studied in terms of reactivity toward CO at 80°C. The reaction probability for CuO nanopowders was estimated to be 2×10−5, which was very close to the value for the nanostructured CuO film. The similarity between the binding energy and reaction probability for additional oxygen states at the surface of CuO nanopowder (531.3eV) and a nanostructured CuO film (530.9eV) confirms its one-type chemical nature, which is likely responsible for its low-temperature catalytic activity. The O/Cu ratio of cleaned nanosized CuO (CuO0.89, Table 4) was ∼10% less than that for bulk CuO. When only lattice oxygen was taken into account, the corresponding O/Cu ratio was found to be only ∼0.7, which confirms the substantial difference between bulk and nanosized CuO. We do not doubt the validity of this result due to the good repeatability of O/Cu values calculated from numerous experiments. Usually, the O/Cu ratio was found to range from 0.85 to 0.9 for the total oxygen quantity, which indicates the presence of anomalous oxygen deficiencies in the CuO nanopowders. The defective non-stoichiometric copper(II) oxides, CuO1±x , and copper(I) oxides, Cu2±y O, have been widely discussed in the literature [76–80]. The stoichiometry deviation is caused by the presence of anionic (oxygen) vacancies, cationic (copper) vacancies and interstitial copper atoms. Values of the x and y parameters in CuO1±x and Cu2±y O typically vary up to 0.05, which is significantly less than the stoichiometry deviation in the CuO nanopowders (CuO1−x , x ∼0.1–0.15) observed in the present work. Notably, the stoichiometry calculations were based on data obtained by XPS, which is a surface-sensitive method. According to the chelatometry results, the Cu content was less than ∼80%, which would be for ideal pure CuO. These results indicate the presence of a stoichiometric excess of oxygen. However, the chelatometry results were obtained for as-prepared samples that contained chemisorbed species (H2O/OH−, CO3 2−/HCO3 −) at the surface. It is likely that the removal of surface/subsurface admixtures followed by chelatometry analysis would result in the same parameter x reported by Carel et al. [80]. Therefore, the discrepancy between the bulk and surface stoichiometries for CuO nanopowders can be related to surface defects that modify its properties, including its catalytic behavior. The relationship between the catalytic activity and the real structure of copper oxide CuO x has been discussed in papers by Sadykov et al. [29,32,81]. The authors reported that the active sites in CO oxidation were clusters of Cu1+ ions with an ability to adsorb CO molecules. Such sites located near extended defects, such as dislocations, polysynthetic twins or interblock boundaries, where the weakly bound oxygen states can also be stabilized. Notably, authors have observed extended defects only for bulk CuO particles with sizes ≥500nm. Opposite to those papers, in this work, the bulk samples with similar sizes (CuO-bulk, CuO-S850) are not characterized by low-temperature catalytic activity toward CO oxidation. The structure of active sites, proposed by Sadykov et al., cannot explain the difference between the catalytic properties of bulk and nanosized CuO particles. However, the enhancement of low-temperature catalytic activity for nanopowders is reliably observed. Nonetheless, the specific surface area of CuO nanopowders cannot be considered as the governing factor for activity because CuO samples with surface areas from 30 to 80m2/g were characterized by similar catalytic behavior toward CO oxidation. Moreover, based on TEM data for all of the studied CuO nanopowders, no extended defects, such as twins or dislocations, were observed in samples in the as-prepared state or in samples exposed to the reaction conditions. Additionally, the appearance of mesopores during the HRTEM studies complicated the analysis of the structure of the CuO nanoparticles, including the analysis of defects. The appearance of a thin Cu2O film epitaxially bound with initial CuO particles can also be related to the highly defective surface structure of the CuO nanopowders and their activity in CO oxidation at low temperatures. The electronic state of copper in the CuO–Cu2O interface can be significantly differ from Cu2+ and Cu1+ species. Probably, such copper species cannot be detected by XPS due to low concentration at the surface in non-reactionary conditions. Epitaxial structures can be active sites of CO oxidation immediately or «an echo» of active metastable phases, which were destroyed after extraction from reactor. The appearance of Cu2O–CuO epitaxy after the treatment in reaction mixture and/or electron beam exposure can be caused by removal of oxygen as follows: (2) 2 CuO 1 − x = Cu 2 O + ( 1 − 2 x ) [ O ] where x =0.1–0.15; [O] can be removed in the form of O2 or CO2 during electron-beam exposure or upon exposure to the reaction conditions (CO+O2), respectively. A large amount of defects at the surface and a small particle size (width) can result in the relaxation of the overall lattice structure and the formation of metastable non-stoichiometric phases [16,28]. Such phases can be formed immediately under the reaction conditions and can be responsible for the low-temperature CO oxidation. Metastable phases such as Cu3O2 and Cu4O3 have been arduously synthesized from other copper oxide states (thin films of Cu3O2 [82,83] and Cu4O3 [84,85]; individual particles of Cu4O3 [86]). The Cu3O2 and Cu4O3 phases can be considered as highly defective copper(II) oxides, CuO1−x (x =0.25, 0.33). Moreover, Medina-Valtierra et al. have reported the catalytic properties of Cu4O3 [85]. The O1s peak shift of the nanosized CuO lattice (529.5eV, Fig. 9(c)) relative to the corresponding peak of bulk CuO (529.8eV, Fig. 9(b)) indicated an overall CuO lattice relaxation during the transition from the micro- to the nanoscale. This transition can be related to the formation of metastable non-stoichiometric phases due to high deficiency in the oxygen sublattice. The transition from bulk to nanosized CuO can also be described by a disproportionation process of the initial bulk lattice oxygen into two states: the majority of oxygen (∼78%, Fig. 9(c)) with E b(O1s)=529.5eV becomes more ionic (metastable structure formation), whereas the remain part with E b(O1s)=531.3eV (∼12%, Fig. 9(c)) becomes less ionic. The overall disproportionation process is likely caused by the partial removal of oxygen from the lattice (∼78%) and by the formation of a highly defective surface structure. The oxygen with E b(O1s)=531.3eV is a relatively weakly bound form, which may be responsible for the low-temperature CO oxidation. Obviously, the changes in the O1s-spectra should be reflected in the Cu2p lines (Fig. 9(a)). However, only a slight shift (Δ =0.3eV) to lower BE values and a slight increase of the shake-up satellite intensity were observed in the Cu2p-spectrum of the nanosized CuO relative to that of the bulk CuO. Assuming the charge redistribution occurred only between oxygen atoms, the absence of ∼10% surface oxygen (x =0.11, CuO0.89, Table 4) must result in a formal charge of copper atoms of +1.8. Such a slight decrease in the charge of copper likely cannot result in the significant difference between the Cu2p-spectra of the bulk and nanosized CuO samples, including the Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 line shifts. The adsorption of CO over Cu1+ sites is well known to be stronger than that over Cu2+ sites [87]. Therefore, a slight decrease in the charge of copper from +2 to +1.8 can result in an enhanced CO adsorption over CuO nanopowders that do not contain Cu1+ sites. The shake-up satellite structure is highly sensitive to changes in the oxygen surroundings due to strong interactions between the Cu3d and O2p bands. The nature of changes in the shake-up satellite structure is not clear to us. It may be related to the geometric distortion of oxygen surroundings at the surface/subsurface CuO layers. Parmigiani et al. discussed the Cu2p features related to a transition from square-planar CuO4 (monoclinic CuO structure) to a pyramidal or an octahedral environment [88]. The authors noted that parameter F also changed, which is the same change we observed for CuO nanopowders. Although the obtained Cu2p-spectra of the bulk and nanosized CuO exhibited no pronounced differences, the valence-band electronic structures are probably significantly different. Revealing these features of the valence band requires the use of ultra-violet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) in a further study. On the basis of the presented data it was proposed the scheme of CO catalytic oxidation over CuO nanopowders. Slight reduction of Cu2+ ions to Cu+1.8 (or Cu+2−δ ) facilitates CO adsorption: (3) CO+Cu+2−δ –O2− =CO–Cu+2−δ –O2− Adsorbed CO molecules can interact with weakly charged oxygen (O− type) forming CO2 and oxygen vacancy. The adsorption sites Cu+2−δ –O2− and Cu+2−δ –O− are assumed to be located close to each other. (4) CO–Cu+2−δ –O2− +Cu+2−δ –O− =CO2 +Cu+2−δ –O2− +Cu+1−δ –[] The O2 adsorption occurs at oxygen vacancies with formation, most probably, molecular species like O2 −. Such species is discussed in terms of low temperature CO oxidation over transition metal oxides [89,90]. (5) O2 +Cu+1−δ –[]=Cu+2−δ –O2 − The O2 − species must be very reactive. Next step of reaction characterizes the interaction between adsorbed CO and weakly bound molecular oxygen with formation of CO2 and O− form regeneration. (6) Cu+2−δ –O2 − +CO–Cu+2−δ –O2− =CO2 +Cu+2−δ –O2− +Cu+2−δ –[O−] At elevated temperatures there is the interaction between adsorbed CO and lattice oxygen. (7) CO–Cu+2−δ –O2− +Cu+2−δ –O2− =CO2 +Cu+1−δ –O2− +Cu+1−δ –[] This step is responsible for the CuO to Cu2O reduction. Note, we observe Cu1+ species and Cu2O islands experimentally by XPS and TEM, respectively. The appearance of Cu1+ sites can get better CO adsorption over nanopowder surface and accelerate the CO oxidation. The Cu1+ sites can also be reoxidized into Cu2+. We would mention that proposed scheme is not totally proved, but, for our opinion, this scheme is most reasonable on the basis of presented experimental results. The XPS data indicate a significant deviation in the stoichiometry in the surfaces of CuO nanopowders from Cu/O=1 (CuO x , x ∼0.1–0.15). Such a deviation does not result in the appearance of Cu1+ ions or local Cu2O structures at the surface. Obviously, the decreased quantity of oxygen must be accompanied by charge compensation. Because of the absence of Cu1+ ions at the surface of the initial CuO nanoparticles, the mechanism of this compensation is probably a cooperative effect that occurs when the overall nanoparticle lattice relaxes with a slight decrease in all of the cationic charges, which can facilitate CO adsorption as well as Cu1+ formation. This process is accompanied by the disproportionation of the anionic sublattice to more-ionic (E b(O1s)=529.5eV) and less-ionic (E b(O1s)=531.3eV) oxygen forms. The decrease in the CuO bond polarity for the reactive oxygen form with BE=531.3eV increases the copper–oxygen distance. This form can be regarded as weakly bound O−-type oxygen. We consider that this state may be responsible for catalytic activity in the CO oxidation reaction at low temperatures over CuO nanopowder catalysts, whereas its absence results in the disappearance of LTA. 5 Conclusions Copper(II) oxide nanopowders with sheet/needle-like particle morphology were prepared by precipitation from strongly alkaline Cu2+ solutions. The variation of the preparation conditions (precursor type, copper concentration, and solvent) resulted in significantly different linear sizes of CuO nanoparticles (widths from 10 to 150nm; lengths from 20 to 1500nm). All of the precipitated dispersed CuO samples exhibited similar catalytic activity in low-temperature CO oxidation. The bulk CuO reference samples with particles sizes of 500–1000nm did not interact with CO at temperatures≤150°C. According to the TGA/TPD-He data, ∼2–4 monolayers of chemisorbed carbon/oxygen-containing species (OH−/H2O, CO3 2−/HCO3 − groups) were revealed at the CuO nanopowders’ surface. The removal of these surface species did not influence the catalytic activity at low temperatures. After surface cleaning of the bulk CuO sample, only the lattice oxygen state (E b (O1s)=529.8eV) was observed by XPS, whereas the surface of the CuO nanopowders was characterized by oxygen deficiencies in the lattice (CuO1−x , x ∼0.1–0.15). These deficiencies resulted in oxygen disproportionation into two forms: more-ionic (E b (O1s)=529.5eV) and less-ionic (E b (O1s)=531.3eV) states in comparison with the lattice oxygen of the bulk CuO oxide. The oxygen form with E b (O1s)=531.3eV was found to be highly reactive toward CO at 80°C (the reaction probability was 2×10−5) and is probably responsible for the low-temperature CO oxidation. A detailed comparison of the Cu2p-spectra for the bulk and nanosized CuO samples revealed only slight differences in the shake-up satellite structures. The transition from the bulk- to the nanoscale significantly modifies the electronic structure of copper(II) oxide. This modification is accompanied by the appearance of defects in the oxygen sublattice and overall CuO lattice distortion, which resulted in changes in the catalytic and adsorption properties. coredata.dc:description: CuO nanopowders were prepared by precipitation from alkaline solutions and were studied by TPR-CO+O2, XRD, TGA, TPD-He and XPS. All of the precipitated samples were characterized by excellent catalytic properties toward the low-temperature (LT) oxidation of CO with similar T 50 values of 110°C. In contrast, bulk CuO oxides with sizes greater than 450nm exhibited no activity at low temperatures. Several monolayers of chemisorbed species, such as water/hydroxyls and carbonate/hydrocarbonates, were typically observed at the surface of the nanopowders. These species were not critical for the LT oxidation of CO, and their preliminary removal did not substantially change the activity of the nanopowders. XPS results indicated a high deficiency of the oxygen sublattice of the CuO1−x (x =0.1–0.15) nanopowders, whereas, for the lattice of bulk CuO, the Cu/O ratio was 1. The highly deficient oxygen sublattice resulted in a disproportionation process, which, in turn, resulted in two observed oxygen forms. An oxygen form with E b(O1s)=531.3eV that is highly reactive toward CO was proposed to be responsible for the high catalytic activity of the CuO nanopowders. Slight differences in the Cu2p shake-up satellite structures were observed between the bulk and nanosized samples, which indicated that the electronic structure in the cationic sublattice had changed.
coredata.dc:title: Study of cupric oxide nanopowders as efficient catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation
